metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2021. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (AV-14TH;3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 2.5 m, 8 m in west of tower), four-component radiometer (PIR&PSP; 12 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (IRTC3; 12 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (LI190SB; 12 m, towards south, vertically upward; another four photosynthetically active radiation, PQS-1; two above the plants (12 m) and two below the plants (0.3 m), towards south, each with one vertically downward and one vertically upward), soil heat flux (HFP01SC; 3 duplicates with G1 below the vegetation; G2 and G3 between plants, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (TCAV; -0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_3 m, WD_5 m, WD_10 m, WD_15 m, WD_20 m, WD_30m, and WD_40 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/ (s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2, and Gs_3, between plants) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content), above the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The soil data during May 15 to June 12 were wrong due to the power loss. TCAV data were missing due to the malfunction of TCAV probe. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2021-6-10 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Concept Completion.Question: Where are soil temperature sensors typically placed in a gradient observation system for agricultural research?
Concept Completion.Answer: Various depths starting from the surface to 160cm underground

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure meteorological parameters in an agricultural setting?
Example.Answer: In an agricultural setting, meteorological parameters such as air temperature, wind speed, and humidity are measured every 10 minutes using a 40-meter boundary layer tower equipped with sensors at various heights. Additionally, four-component radiations are measured at 12 meters above the ground, and turbulent fluxes are measured at 4.5 meters using an eddy covariance system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting accurate data for soil and canopy component temperatures?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting accurate data for soil and canopy component temperatures is the error in derived component temperature caused primarily by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Misclassification of soil pixels as vegetation pixels can lead to overestimation of the canopy temperature, especially as vegetation abundance develops.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in an oasis–desert area?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in an oasis–desert area consists of long-term data from 2012 to 2021, including turbulent fluxes and hydrometeorological data. This dataset also contains vegetation and soil parameters, collected from multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations established in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin in western China.

Feature Specification.Answer: long-term energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, hydrometeorology, vegetation parameters, soil parameters, ecological degradation, drying rivers, vegetation degradation, desertification

Feature Specification.Question: What specific characteristics are considered in the gradient meteorological observations for agricultural research?
Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, wind speed and direction, humidity, four-component radiation, soil temperature, soil moisture

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'data processing and quality control procedure' in the context of long-term environmental data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of long-term environmental data collection, 'data processing and quality control procedure' refers to the systematic approach to collecting, handling, and verifying the integrity and accuracy of observational data. This involves ensuring data completeness, removing erroneous data, standardizing formats, and archiving data for accessibility, which are crucial steps to maintain the reliability of datasets over time.

Definition.Question: What does 'component temperatures' signify in the context of estimating evapotranspiration using remote sensing techniques?
Definition.Answer: 'Component temperatures' in this context signify the distinct temperatures of different elements within a landscape, such as soil and canopy, observed using remote sensing techniques. These measurements are critical for models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, which require accurate temperature readings to estimate processes such as evaporation, transpiration, and overall evapotranspiration more accurately.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for monitoring meteorological parameters at the Daman superstation compare to those used in the artificial and natural oasis–desert systems in terms of frequency and types of measurements?
Comparison.Answer: At the Daman superstation, meteorological parameters are measured every 10 minutes and include air temperature, wind speed, humidity, and four-component radiations, while the oasis–desert systems collect half-hourly turbulent flux data using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, with additional 10-minute average hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of estimating evapotranspiration using the TSEB model differ from the challenges of maintaining the ecological balance in oasis–desert areas?
Comparison.Answer: The TSEB model faces challenges in accurately estimating component temperatures and dealing with complex resistances, particularly under strongly advective conditions, whereas oasis–desert areas face broader ecological challenges such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and increased dust storms.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of multiple sensor layers in a meteorological observation system enhance the accuracy and reliability of data related to atmospheric phenomena?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of multiple sensor layers in a meteorological observation system, as described in the field, allows for a comprehensive collection of data across different heights and conditions. This setup can enhance accuracy by capturing variations in wind speed, temperature, and humidity at different altitudes, which are crucial for understanding atmospheric phenomena. The redundancy of measurements at various levels also helps in cross-verifying data and ensuring reliability, especially when dealing with complex interactions between surface and atmospheric processes.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can integrating ground-based measurements with thermal imaging enhance the interpretation of surface energy balance models in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements with thermal imaging can significantly enhance the interpretation of surface energy balance models in heterogeneous landscapes by providing detailed spatial and temporal data on soil and canopy temperatures. This integration allows for the accurate partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration components, as ground-based sensors provide continuous data on meteorological parameters, while thermal imaging captures high-resolution temperature variations. Such a combined approach addresses the challenges of accurately estimating surface fluxes, especially in areas with mixed soil and vegetation, thereby improving model validation and reliability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the data processing and quality control methods applied to meteorological and flux datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The data processing and quality control methods are necessary to ensure the accuracy and reliability of observations due to potential challenges in data collection, such as ecological environment degradation, drying up of water sources, and the sensitive nature of oasis–desert ecosystems. These methods help in maintaining data integrity and supporting ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately measure evapotranspiration components in irrigated agricultural areas using remote sensing models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately measuring evapotranspiration components is challenging due to the heterogeneous nature of the landscape, which includes varying soil and vegetation temperatures and resistances to energy exchange. Errors can occur in surface–air temperature difference calculations and image classification, which affect the estimation of component temperatures and subsequently the performance of remote sensing models like the TSEB.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of long-term observational datasets in understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial due to the dynamic and complex interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are influenced by climate change, ecological degradation, and human activities. These datasets help in recognizing interactions, maintaining ecological stability, and supporting sustainable development goals in arid and semiarid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of isotopic techniques in the validation of evapotranspiration estimates impact the understanding of water cycle dynamics in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating isotopic techniques enhances the understanding of water cycle dynamics by providing a more detailed separation of evaporation and transpiration components. This allows for better validation and refinement of evapotranspiration models, leading to improved water resource management and ecological assessments in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to collect and analyze meteorological parameters such as wind speed, air temperature, and soil moisture in the context of the Heihe River Basin ecosystem?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting and analyzing meteorological parameters is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is significant for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development of oases in arid and semiarid areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to utilize long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are necessary to quantitatively understand the interactions between oasis and desert systems. This knowledge is crucial for protecting ecological stability, supporting socioeconomic development, and addressing environmental challenges such as land degradation and desertification in arid and semiarid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the Eddy Covariance (EC) system utilized in conjunction with other meteorological instruments to measure energy fluxes in a heterogeneous landscape?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The EC system measures turbulent fluxes at 4.5m above the ground with a 10 Hz sampling frequency, while meteorological parameters like air temperature, wind speed, and humidity are measured every 10 minutes at various heights. Additional measurements include four-component radiations at 12m using a radiometer and soil heat fluxes from heat plates buried 6cm underground. These instruments collectively allow partitioning of evapotranspiration into soil evaporation and canopy transpiration using models like TSEB, validated by isotope techniques and EC measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux datasets in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure dataset accuracy, observations from long-term flux measurements are supplemented by auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, soil, and vegetation parameters. Data are processed and quality-controlled by collecting half-hourly turbulent flux data, 10-minute meteorological data, and groundwater table data, with automated weather stations and supplemental vegetation and soil measurements. Data processing includes collection, quality checks, and archiving for sharing, ensuring reliability for understanding oasis-desert interactions.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures for estimating evapotranspiration in agricultural areas?
Enablement.Answer: The use of ground-based observations such as a high-resolution thermal camera and meteorological parameters from boundary layer towers enable accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures. This data is crucial for estimating evapotranspiration using models like the TSEB model in agricultural areas.

Enablement.Question: How do long-term observational datasets facilitate the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observational datasets that include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data like hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, are essential. They provide crucial insights into the interactions and ecological stability of oasis–desert ecosystems, supporting sustainable development and carbon neutrality goals.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements or conditions enable the measurement of turbulent fluxes in arid and semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The deployment of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers at land surface flux stations enables the measurement of turbulent fluxes in arid and semi-arid regions. These technologies offer high-frequency data collection, which is critical for understanding the dynamics of energy and water vapor exchanges in these regions.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in separating soil and vegetation component temperatures for evapotranspiration estimation models in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: In arid regions, accurately estimating surface fluxes is challenging due to strong advective conditions and errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures. Image classification errors, atmospheric radiation effects, and uncertainties in radiation transmittances through the canopy contribute to challenges in separating component temperatures.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the data collection techniques employed in obtaining meteorological and soil data within the oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection techniques in oasis–desert ecosystems involve using eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations. These methods provide comprehensive measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Despite the robust data collection framework, challenges such as environmental degradation and the need for long-term observations to support ecological security and sustainable development are significant considerations in evaluating these techniques.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how data collection methods address the challenges of capturing accurate energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems.
Assertion.Answer: Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Additionally, hydrometeorological data were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period, which includes radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and more, ensuring comprehensive data capture.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how datasets can effectively capture the interactions between soil and vegetation in heterogeneous landscapes with mixed temperatures and resistances.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets from the field include data from a multi-scale observation experiment that used both ground-based measurements and thermal infrared images to partition evapotranspiration into soil and canopy components. The Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model was used to estimate these interactions by separating latent heat fluxes of soil and vegetation components.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods for meteorological and soil parameters in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods in oasis–desert ecosystems involve a combination of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane flux measurements using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Additionally, hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and direction are collected using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Vegetation and soil parameters are also supplemented to support comprehensive analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in estimating surface fluxes include incomplete energy balance closure in eddy covariance (EC) flux measurements, uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, errors in surface soil and vegetation component temperature determination, and strong advective conditions affecting measurement accuracy. Image classification errors and ignoring atmospheric factors can also introduce uncertainties, particularly in the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the potential datasets available for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas include long-term observational data from artificial and natural ecosystems. These datasets consist of half-hourly turbulent flux data, hydrometeorological observations, and auxiliary data on vegetation and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. The data are collected from multiple stations, including superstations and ordinary stations, and are available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
